title.value: Reputation Gaming in Crowd Technical Knowledge Sharing
title.justification: The title clearly reflects the central theme of the research paper, which is about the manipulation of reputation systems in crowd technical knowledge sharing platforms like Stack Overflow.
title.quote: Reputation Gaming in Crowd Technical Knowledge Sharing

extractions.description: This paper investigates the manipulation of reputation systems on platforms like Stack Overflow, identifying fraud scenarios such as voting rings and developing algorithms to automatically detect these manipulations. It aims to improve fraud detection mechanisms and enhance the overall trust and quality of shared knowledge.

type.justification: The study is based on the empirical analysis of 1,697 posts from Stack Overflow meta-sites and includes the development and evaluation of algorithms to detect reputation fraud.
type.quote: We report the results from two empirical studies. The studies offer insights into how exploitation may happen based on diverse reputation fraud scenarios and whether such suspicious reputations can be identified.

name.justification: The paper focuses on the exploitation and detection of reputation systems within technical knowledge sharing platforms like Stack Overflow.
name.quote: The recognition of developers in Stack Overflow is aided through the reputation/incentive system.

name.justification: The research involves understanding reputation manipulation in collaborative platforms, reflecting interests in social computing aspects.
name.quote: • Human-centered computing → Collaborative and social computing; • Collaborative and social computing systems and tools → Reputation systems;

name.justification: The paper develops algorithms to detect suspicious reputation activities in Stack Overflow, which places it in the field of algorithms research.
name.quote: We developed algorithms that enable platform managers to automatically identify these suspicious reputation gaming scenarios for review.

name.justification: The study uses the SOTorrent dataset version September 2018 for analyzing suspicious community detection.
name.quote: For Algorithm 1, we used the SOTorrent dataset of September 2018.

referenced_paper_title.value: SOTorrent: Reconstructing and analyzing the evolution of stack overflow posts
referenced_paper_title.justification: This dataset reference provides insight into the source of data used for the analysis presented in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: SOTorrent: Reconstructing and analyzing the evolution of stack overflow posts
